Description.val: Repair and Test Equipment Budget Line Item provides repair and test equipment consisting of more than 200 different items required to support the operation and maintenance of USMC ground based weapon systems and major end items.  Repair and test equipment includes items such as tool kits, shop sets, manual and automatic test equipment, as well as metrology and calibration equipment.  The following acquisition programs fall under the repair and test equipment budget line: General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS); Automatic Test Systems (ATS), Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP), and Marine Air-Ground Task Force (MAGTF) Logistics Support Systems (MLS2).

Justification.val:
FY2018 Baseline Appropriation Request: $29.613M (ACTIVE:$38.117M/RESERVE:$0.000M)

General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $4.754M:  The GPT&TS budget procures a wide variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20-ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings.  All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems located within USMC expeditionary battalions and squadrons.  FY18 funding procured new water cooled Mobile Lube Unit air compressors, Expeditionary Fuel Test Shop, and hardware and software required for Fuel Test Stand Application Program Sets that support maintenance efforts on new fuel components (pumps and injectors).  Funding procured engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items.  The General Mechanics Tool Kit (GMTK) had a fact of life reduction of FY18 quantities and funding to zero due to an Army GMTK contract that was awarded in FY18 and later canceled due to vendor protest.  Due to Army acquisition change, funds re-directed to procure Fuel Test Stand Test Program Sets to meet higher priority requirement.

Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $25.163M:  Funding supported procurement of Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) kits to enhance capability and mitigate against obsolescence for Automatic Test Systems (ATS) such as the General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), Ground Radio Maintenance Automatic Test System (GRMATS), and associated applications that enable ATS to test weapon system platforms. These ATS provide mobile automatic testing on Line Replaceable Units (LRU) and Circuit Card Assemblies (CCA), enabling rapid restoration of weapon systems.  ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provides mobile and automatic testing on Principle End Items (PEI), Line Replaceable Units (LRU), and Shop Repairable Units (SRU) in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs of supported weapon systems.  Specific Application Program Systems (APS) procurements for FY18 included the Light Armored Vehicle Anti-Tank (LAV-AT) LRU APS and Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT) APS.

Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $0.576M:  Funding supported the necessary modifications and updates to the Marine Corps Field Level Calibration Facility (AN/TSM-214A). There are twelve fielded Calibration
Facilities, with each consisting of four twenty-foot International Organization for Standardization (ISO) containers and a wide variety of Calibration Standards and support equipment. This facility is designed for
expeditionary deployments and use in austere environments. Various Calibration Standards, controllers (work stations), and software must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test
equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.   FY18 funding procured new Windows 10 equipment set replacements for the legacy Windows 7 Digital Analysis Control Group that is utilized in the deployed calibration facilities.

MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $7.624M:  Funding procured Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS).  FY18 funds procured Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment that comprises the EMSS and technical support for fielded systems.  The EMSS provides a Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) hardware device equipped with Built-In-Test/Built-In-Test Equipment (BIT/BITE) interfaces, and Software Defined Test Instrument (SDTI) that provides capabilities such as Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications. EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions, thereby improving readiness.  EMSS connected to the MCEN were demonstrated to provide maintainers a time savings of upwards of 15% per task and 40 minutes per day based on their average workload.  Operating software is no longer required in FY18 and out due to a USMC enterprise transition from an end-device subscription model to an end-user subscription model.  Funding re-directed to fund additional technical support requirements (See Cost Element 1.4 for details). 

FY2019 Baseline Appropriation Request: $45.656M (ACTIVE:$45.656M, RESERVE:$0.000M)

General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $13.329M:  The GPT&TS budget procures a wide variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20-ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings.  All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems located within USMC expeditionary battalions and squadrons.  FY19 funding includes the procurement of a new technology of Additive Manufacturing (also known as 3D printing) to enhance our existing fabrication capability using fielded machine shops.  FY19 funding will procure portable electronic test sets such as Radio Test Sets, Microwave Radio and Radar Test Sets, Microwave Signal Generators, Data Network Testers, and Fluid Analyzers.  The Microwave Signal Generators and Data Network Testers were added to the FY19 effort due to urgent need to support readiness issues with microwave radios such as VSAT.  Due to an acquisition strategy change, the Vehicle Automated Diagnostic System (VADS) program moved to the Automatic Test Systems program and funding re-directed to procure other higher priority requirements, Microwave Signal Generator and Data Network Tester.  FY19 funding procures large mechanical test stands and associated equipment necessary to test vehicle components.  These test items include engine and transmission dynamometers and fuel test stands.  In addition, funding will procure engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items.  The General Mechanics Tool Kit (GMTK) had a fact of life reduction of FY19 quantities and funding to zero due to an Army GMTK contract that was awarded in FY18 and later canceled due to vendor protest.  Due to Army acquisition change, funds re-directed to increase FY19 quantities and unit cost for Operators Fluid Analysis Test Sets.  Unit cost increase supports additional capability for additive hardware that will expand on the Tier I capability and quantities increased to meet AAO.

Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $9.958M:  Funding supports procurement of the Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) Test Station modernized replacement system as well as Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) kits to enhance capability and mitigate against obsolescence for the General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), Technical Manual publication, Ground Radio Maintenance Automatic Test System (GRMATS) ECPs, and Application Program Sets (APS) production that enable ATS to test multiple Marine Corps ground systems, such as the Very Small Aperture Terminal (VSAT) APS.  ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provides mobile and automatic testing on Line Replaceable Units (LRU) and CCA in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs.

Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $11.916M: Funding procures two lightened Shop Equipment, Calibration (SEC), previously known as Expeditionary Calibration Facilities.  These shops are designed for expeditionary deployments and use in austere environments to support MAGTF deployed operations and will provide warfighters with a lighter, smaller expeditionary calibration capability.  Funding will also procure various calibration equipment.  Various calibration equipment, controllers (work stations), and software must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.

MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $10.453M:  Funding continues to procure Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS) to address AAO shortfalls.  FY19 funding will procure items such as Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment, operating software that comprises the EMSS and technical support.  EMSS includes Built-In-Test/Built- In-Test Equipment (BIT/BITE) interfaces and Software Defined Test Instrument (SDTI) that enables capabilities such as storing and viewing Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications.  EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions, thereby improving readiness.  EMSS connected to the MCEN were demonstrated to provide maintainers a time savings of upwards of 15% per task and 40 minutes per day based on their average workload.  Electronic Maintenance Device (EMD) hardware was broken into two separate cost elements, "EMD Hardware" and "EMD Hardware CF20".  This reflects two separate procurements off of two separate USMC contracts.  The EMD acquisition strategy was updated for FY19 and FY20 procurements due to an Army contract protest.  As a result of the current Army contract protest, "EMD Hardware" will be procured off an existing in-house blanket purchase agreement (BPA) contract, and "EMD Hardware CF20" will be procured off a new in-house BPA that will be awarded 2QFY19.  The EMD acquisition strategy change will allow the USMC to field additional systems sooner in order to reduce AAO shortages and improve maintenance capabilities for ground weapon systems.  Operating software is no longer required due to a USMC enterprise transition from an end-device subscription model to an end-user subscription model.  Funding re-directed to fund additional technical support requirements (See Cost Element 1.4 for details).

FY2020 Baseline Appropriation Request: $55.156M (ACTIVE:$55.156M, RESERVE:$0M)

General Purpose Tools and Test Systems (GPT&TS) $23.753M:  The GPT&TS budget procures a wide variety of portable tool kits, large tool shop sets (mounted on vehicles or trailers or contained within 20ft shelters), handheld electronic test equipment, handheld mechanical test equipment, and large mechanical test equipment contained in shelters or buildings.  All of these items are commercial off the shelf or modified commercial off the shelf type equipment that are required to support the field maintenance effort of USMC ground equipment and weapon systems located within USMC expeditionary battalions and squadrons.  FY20 funding continues the procurement of a new technology of Additive Manufacturing (also known as 3D printing) to enhance our existing fabrication capability using fielded machine shops.  FY20 includes production of large shelter based X-FAB and the initial procurement of small portable (transit case based) TAC-FAB 3D printing capability.  Increase $10.424M from FY19 to FY20 is primarily a result of new Additive Manufacturing (3D printing) capability but also addresses the need to continue procurement efforts of additional portable electronic test sets such as Microwave Comm and Radar Test Sets, Microwave Signal Generators, Data Network Testers, Fluid analyzers and increased quantities for the Fire Bottle Refill Shops (contained in a trailer mounted 20-ft container).  Funding also procures items such as engine and transmission dynamometers and fuel test stands, as well as engineering, logistics, system software support, and cyber security efforts for the entire portfolio of GPT&TS items.  Increased support in FY20 aligns to the procurement and fielding plan for equipment such as X-FAB, TACFAB and multiple test sets.  PB19 to PB20 change for the Operators Fluid Analysis Test Set reflects unit cost increase to support additional capability for additive hardware that will expand on the Tier I capability.  

Automatic Test Systems (ATS) $9.046M:  Funding will support procurement of the Circuit Card Assembly (CCA) Test Station modernized replacement system as well as Engineer Change Proposal (ECP) modernization kits to the ATS Family of Systems such as General Purpose Automatic Test System (GPATS), Ground Radio Maintenance Automatic Test System (GRMATS), and Application Program Sets (APS).  These ECPs will enhance organic maintenance capabilities and mitigate against obsolescence.  ATS consists of both hardware and software components that provides mobile and automatic testing on Principle End Items (PEI), Line Replaceable Units (LRU), and Shop Repairable Units (SRU) in order to improve weapon system readiness, provide an organic maintenance solution, and decrease life cycle costs of supported weapon systems.  The $0.912M decrease from FY19 to FY20 aligns to the procurement plan for Automatic Test Equipment.

Calibration and Maintenance Program (CAMP) $11.817M: Funding will procure two lighter Shop Equipment, Calibration (SEC), previously known as Expeditionary Calibration Facilities. These shops are designed for expeditionary deployments and use in austere environments to support MAGTF deployed operations.  These shops will provide warfighters with a lighter, smaller, and expeditionary calibration capability.  Funding will also procure various calibration equipment. Various calibration equipment, controllers (work stations), and software must be replaced/upgraded over time in order to support and calibrate all the different test equipment used by various maintenance personnel working on USMC ground military equipment.

MAGTF Logistics Support Systems (MLS2) $10.540M:  Funding continues to procure Electronic Maintenance Support Systems (EMSS) to address AAO shortfalls.  FY20 funding will procure items such as Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) equipment, operating software that comprises the EMSS, and technical support.  EMSS will emulate and/or interface with test equipment and enables capabilities such as storing and viewing Interactive Electronic Technical Manuals (IETMs), Computer Based Training (CBT), and other maintenance applications.  EMSS also has the capability to connect to the Marine Corps Enterprise Network (MCEN) and access sites like Global Combat Support System - Marine Corps (GCSS-MC) in order to facilitate maintenance and supply transactions thereby improving readiness.  EMSS connected to the MCEN was demonstrated to provide maintainers a time savings of upwards of 15% per task and 40 minutes per day based on their average workload.  Electronic Maintenance Device (EMD) hardware was broken into two separate cost elements, "EMD Hardware" and "EMD Hardware CF20".  This reflects two separate procurements off of two separate USMC contracts.  The EMD acquisition strategy was updated for FY19 and FY20 procurements due to an Army contract protest.  As a result of the current Army contract protest, "EMD Hardware" will be procured off an existing in-house blanket purchase agreement (BPA) contract, and "EMD Hardware CF20" will be procured off a new in-house BPA that will be awarded 2QFY19.  The EMD acquisition strategy change will allow the USMC to field additional systems sooner in order to reduce AAO shortages and improve maintenance capabilities for ground weapon systems.  Operating software is no longer required due to a USMC enterprise transition from an end-device subscription model to an end-user subscription model.  Funding re-directed to additional technical support requirements (See Cost Element 1.4 for details).  The technical support increase from FY19 to FY20 funds additional requirements such as technical support for increased EMD fielded quantities, cyber security requirements for network connected systems, enhanced diagnostic software, and to merge EMD and Vehicle Automate Diagnostic System (VADS) capabilities which will decrease system lifecycle costs and logistics footprint.

OCO: 
FY 2018 Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) Request:  $8.504M 
Automatic Test Systems (ATS) funds will be used to procure 9 Virtual Instrument Portable Equipment Repair/Tester (VIPER/T) systems.  These systems are used while deployed to field test, align, and repair vehicle components for Special Purpose MAGTFs (SPMAGTF).
